38108383.review:
[i]Snakebird[/i] is a meticulously crafted puzzler: it starts with levels just easy enough to properly convey the game's mechanics and then ratchets up the complexity in carefully sequenced increments. The main game ends with some genuinely challenging levels; thankfully a level that has you stumped can be saved for later because the game unlocks levels generously and doesn't let you grind to a halt until you're actually approaching the end.

As you succeed in clearing each zone of the main map, you'll gain access to one of six incredibly difficult "star" levels. Any one of these is brain-knotting enough to keep you seeing floating fruit in your sleep for many nights to come.

15个小时，我终于凭借自己的力量打通了这个游戏，真是酣畅淋漓。（然而时隔一两个月又会忘记解法，可重玩性max）
总的来说，这是一款披着人畜无害的可爱外皮的硬核解谜游戏。作者用寥寥几种解谜元素创造出了50+道困难且极富创意的谜题。与其他循序渐进的休闲向解谜游戏不同，在简单介绍了机制之后，就立刻带来了十足困难的谜题，强迫你探索与发现简单机制的复杂运用。所幸，游戏没有强迫你死钻仅仅一个谜题，大多时候你是在4~5个谜题中辗转，试图寻找突破口。在研究谜题时，还附有轻松明快的BGM和音效让你感到偷税（当然有时也会听腻）。
最后我不想用一个分数来评价这款游戏，这款游戏对我这样的解谜游戏爱好者来说是绝对必玩的，但不推荐不喜欢静下来思考的人游玩。

At first glance it may look like a simple child's game but is in fact [b]one of the best puzzlers around[/b]. The visuals suit the game very well and are cute but do not distract from the actual puzzles.

The puzzles feature are a combination of snake(bird)s that have to reach an exit on a grid-based map. The levels/puzzles are grouped by themes/objects that they introduce to allow for more complex mechanics.

36762664.review: Vu de loin Snakebird ressemble à un (non) jeu pour téléphone portable avec son graphisme coloré qui évoque furieusement Angry Birds. Sauf qu'il cache en réalité un redoutable puzzle game. De prime abord ça paraît simple. Après quelques tentatives infructueuses ça se révèle difficile. Et quand on commence à coincer sérieusement le défi semble carrément impossible. Ce qu'il n'est évidemment pas mais ce level design a de toute évidence été inspiré par un esprit démoniaque ! Le jeu consiste à amener un ou plusieurs serpents qui évoluent en case par case jusqu'à une sortie (et éventuellement à débloquer celle-ci en mangeant les fruits disséminés dans le niveau - sachant que chaque fois qu'un serpent mange un fruit il s'agrandit façon Centipede). Toute la difficulté consiste à conserver des points d'appui pour faire évoluer nos serpents (en particulier ceux-ci peuvent grimper les uns sur les autres) et à ne pas les bloquer dans une impasse. Je me répète mais tout le génie de Snakebird vient de son level design absolument machiavélique, soit qu'il laisse une impression de facilité aussitôt démentie dans la pratique, soit au contraire qu'il propose une situation qui semble totalement impossible a priori. Un titre indispensable pour les amateurs de puzzle game.

36313115.review:
I love this game for two reasons: its incredibly cute aesthetic, and the difficulty of the puzzles.  

The snakebirds are abolsutely adorable! The game's motion, sounds, environments, and background music all go really well together.

I also love the depth of the puzzles. They are pretty tough, and often require you to really plan ahead. Indeed, don't let your guard down just becaue of the cutesy aesthetic - this is a difficult puzzle game. Children might find it a bit tough and frustrating. (I found it frustrating at times!)

I also like the 'quality of life' features, like not having a strict progression of puzzles, so even if you are stuck you can keep playing other adjacent levels. Also, within each level you have the ability to easily and quickly undo any number of moves or reset the level, which really helps you as you ponder what the solution might be and avoids having to repeat yourself too much.  

One criticism I have is that one of the key controls might not be very well tutorialised. Maybe I just missed it, but I didn't know how to switch which bird I was controlling the first time I was confronted with a multi-bird puzzle, and I had to look it up.  

Still, its a great game, and I really enjoyed it.

I got it as part of a Humble Bundle product a while ago, and it certainly contributed to making that purchase worthwhile.

35668184.review:
As many have noted, the friendly-casual surface of this game belies a disturbing, even hideous challenge level.  These 'birds' may be more truthfully perceived as tentacular offshoots of some eldritch horror; the 'fruit' they seek---doomed souls.

That said, it's a really good puzzle game!  The core mechanic is novel and dynamic enough to lead to very interesting and tricky situations (especially when more than one snakebird are involved), but it is still rooted enough in spatial movement to feel intuitive.  Seemingly impossible situations gradually reveal a path to victory, with a rich variety of 'trick moves' arising out of the simple ground rules.

I'm at ~42/53 puzzles completed as I write this.  Most people should expect to chip away at this one slowly, but it is quite satisfying to make progress.

35133913.review:
[h1]Описание:[/h1]
Головоломка. Перед нами гибрид птицы и змеи - змеептица, которая питается фруктами и оттого удлиняется в размерах. Нашей задачей на каждом уровне является доставить всех змеептиц до портала и тем самым мы открываем следующие уровни на карте. Уровни разделены по локациям, в каждой из которых есть своя изюминка. Игра сложна и в большинстве случаев уровень имеет одно-два решений для прохождения, а вариаций ходов великое множество. И нужно включать мозги, методом проб и ошибок пытаться пройти до заветного портала.

[h1]Плюсы:[/h1]
¥ Игра не имеет совершенно никакого текста (кроме меню), а значит отлично подходит для русскоязычных игроков.
¥ Интересные достижения. Вернее интересная только одна ачивка, а все остальные просто на прохождение игры. В этой самой ачивке мы должны прокликать все анимированные декорации в игре. Мне это очень понравилось )
¥ Нелинейное прохождение. Проходя один уровень, мы открываем несколько окружающих и вполне может получиться так, что пройдя допустим второй уровень, мы сразу перекинемся на сороковой или сверхсложный со звездочкой.
¥ Облачное сохранение. После формата даже не ожидал, что игра сохранит мой прогресс. Но к моему удивлению, вернувшись в игру после формата меня вернуло на уровень, где сохранились даже сделанные на уровне ходы. Браво.
¥ Управление. Мы можем управлять как мышью, так и клавиатурой, удобно переключаясь между змеептицами.
¥ Откат ходов назад. В этой игре невозможно проиграть и нет никакого таймера, который куда-то торопит. Сделав неправильный ход, мы можем одним нажатием клавиши вернуть все назад настолько насколько это нужно.

[h1]Минусы:[/h1]
¥ Уровни проходятся в основном одним решением и порою трудно догадаться как делать действительно правильно. Становится морально сложно играть.
¥ Неудачный саундтрек.

[h1]Итог:[/h1]
Симпатичная игра, со своей изюминкой и механикой, но в то-же время строго на любителя. Причем на любителя конкретно этой игры, а не головоломок в целом. Вам нужно посмотреть трейлер и сто раз подумать стоит ли начинать играть. Я играл через силу разделив прохождение на несколько вечеров, когда бывает такое особое настроение под подобные игры. Игра не плохая, но и не хорошая. Нейтральная оценка. Т.к. у меня эмоций больше отрицательных, то палец вниз.

[h1]Оценка: 5/10[/h1]

[h1]Послесловие:[/h1]
Если вам понравился этот обзор добро пожаловать в группу
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/uojer - тут вы сможете увидеть рекомендованные мною игры, другие обзоры, а также просто пообщаться в хорошей компании.

34703138.review:
So Snakebird starts out decently enough but quickly devolves down into an obnoxious brute force "puzzle" game.

Here's the game in a nutshell. Levels are laid out as a square grid. You'll control 1-3 snakes which will each be a certain number of squares long. On levels with multiple snakes, pressing tab will select a different one. Some levels will have fruit. If it has fruit, you must eat the fruit with a snake which will make the snake 1 square bigger. Once all fruit is eaten, the exit to the level opens. If there's no fruit, then the exit begins open and you must navigate your snake(s) to the exit. The trick to the game is that the snakes will fall based on their current shape if they're no longer touching the ground. So you often need to shape your snake a particular way so falling causes it to land on a platform rather than a spike trap or off the bottom of the level. Snakes can also push each other if you ram another one, you'll often need to do this to get another snake to certain spots. At any time, you can reset a level or press backspace to undo moves as far as you want. If you die, the game automatically undoes your last move.

The music and graphics are fine. The game controls decently well. It starts out fine enough but quickly shows its ugly head.

Minor Quibble: If you're moving your snake around to solve the 'puzzles' and die on a level (and you will die many times) the game backs up 1 turn. If you have multiple snakes, the game selects the snake that died rather than the snake that moved. So once the game undoes your move, you'll go to move the snake you were using only to discover that the game has selected the other snake as the active snake instead. So you've driven that snake somewhere you didn't want it to go and have to undo moves and then select the other snake. This is a minor issue, but it will happen very frequently and is annoying. Why not just leave the active snake as the active snake when the death gets undone? I can't imagine what sort of idiotic reasoning the game designers had for making it this way.

So the biggest problem this game has is that each level isn't so much a puzzle as it is a brute force method of elimination. Most levels require that your snake(s) be moved in a specific manner. If you do not move in the exact manner the level designer wants you to, you will fail.  Quick example:  You need to move somewhere 4 spaces away, so you could choose to move (up, up, right, right) or (right, right, up up) or (up, right, up, right) or (right, up, right, up).  All viable right?  Well not in Snakebird.  In Snakebird, only one of those choices might allow you to succeed.  Now imagine your Snake is bigger and/or you have multiple snakes, all of which must move in specific manners.  This is what you do every single level.  All you're really doing is making a best guess as to whether a path you're taking is the right one until you either succeed or eliminate every possibility it contains and then do the same for some other path until you finally pick the right pathway. There's never really any moments where you get excited or feel good for figuring something out, you just go “Well, I guessed the correct path that 23rd time”. It feels as though the level designers made the levels starting at the end rather then the beginning, traced a specific path that each snake must make from the end back to a certain point, then set that as the start point, and then designed the levels around the pre-made paths. Levels are designed in a way that you could divide them up into several parts. You might clear 1 or 2 parts only to discover at part 3 that you didn't clear part 1 or 2 in the specific manner you were supposed to.  Have fun going back to part 2 or maybe all the way back to part 1.

After brute forcing my way through several levels, I'd had enough. I never felt like I was doing something thoughtful but instead was just punishing myself looking for that 1 and only 1 specific path. It feels like a mindless grind rather than something thought provoking that lead to a solution.

Edit: To further clarify since I've had some comments. I never claimed there's anything wrong with one pathway puzzle games, I enjoy plenty of them. The problem is that this one is a lemon. It offers nothing thoughtful.  Snakebird is a maze variant.  The best strategy for beating a maze?  Start at the end and work backwards, it's the same here in Snakebird.  This is a strategy I figured out for mazes by the age of 5-6.  If you consider tracing paths backwards to be thought provoking and a real brain burner, boy are you in for a treat. Consider this: All you do in the game is move up, left, right, & down and on some levels switch your snakes. Sounds incredibly simple right? We should all be able to beat a game this simple in a few hours right? So, how do you extend the playtime of something this simple? Easy, make it unfair.

People seem confused about the brute forcing parts, so I'm going to ELI 8 this for people. Let's look at how you play a maze, there are 2 methods.  1. Draw as you go:  You use a pencil, start at the start point and draw a path until you reach an area where you can go in multiple directions (a decision point).  You then glance at the maze and make a best guess which way to go.  If it leads to another decision point, do the same thing.  If it leads to a dead end, you erase your path back to the decision point, glance at the maze, and make a new best guess.  Repeat until you get to the exit.  2. Trace and then draw:  This works the same exact way as number 1, except you wait to draw your path until you've traced your way to the exit.  It's important to note that it doesn't matter whether you actually drew a path into a dead end or traced your finger into a dead end, you ran into the dead end.  They are the same exact things.  Mazes don't require intelligence to solve.  The best you can do at any given point is make a best guess where you should go and do that over and over and over until it succeeds.  This is brute forcing.  Now let's look at Snakebird.  How can you play Snakebird?  Well, there are 2 ways.  Let's assume we're on a level with 3 fruits.  1. Move as you play:  In this method, you move your Snakebird until you hit a decision point.  You glance at all the fruit and make a best guess as to which one you can get.  You then move your Snakebird to it and attempt to get it.  If you get it, you glance at the remaining fruit and make a new best guess as to which one you can get.  If you fail to get the fruit (either because you're too short, you block yourself out, you fall into the abyss, or fall into a spike), then you undo your moves until you're back at the decision point, glance at the remaining fruit, and make a new best guess.  Repeat until you get all fruit and into the exit.  2: Trace and then move:  This works the same exact way as number 1, except you wait to move your Snakebird until you've successfully traced a working path to a piece of fruit or to all fruits and into the exit.  Again, it's important to note that it doesn't matter whether you moved your Snakebird and fell off a ledge/onto a spike or traced a path where you realized your Snakebird would fall off a ledge/onto a spike, you still died.  They are the exact same things.  The problems with Snakebird are the exact same problems a maze has.  You're simply brute forcing best guesses until they work.  Again, it doesn't matter whether you're actually moving your Snakebird around or just tracing paths in your head, you're doing the exact same things.

If you want to see exactly what I'm talking about, one of the commenters has videos of himself playing this.  Click on the comments, find the profile of “Edderiofer” (who does not agree with the way I reviewed this game) and click on his profile.  Then take 2-5 minutes to watch a video of him playing this game to see solid evidence that what I've written is entirely accurate.

33282670.review:
Normally I view the recommendation system on Steam more so about personal preferences rather than if a game is good or bad, but no matter how many issues I have with Snakebird I cannot put it into the latter category because I’m simply bad at these types of puzzles. Feeling inept at something deceptively simple is rather the point of Snakebird with the kid-friendly exterior masquerading the challenge of wrapping your head around these elaborate solutions. If the puzzles can make you realize what you did wrong, then the puzzles themselves are not at fault; it’s yourself to blame for not understanding them. 

However, I feel like Snakebird doesn’t do enough to shift the blame entirely on the player for not getting it. The core mechanics as well as the additional challenges are fine and they’re handled with excellent level-design, but the difficulty spikes of more complexity and choice to pick your battles is something that brought me more frustration than satisfaction. As a result, I can only suggest people who like to micromanage solutions in their head more than fiddling with their hands would enjoy Snakebird.

[h1]Is it a Bird? Is it a Snake?[/h1] 

A lot of people describe this game as any other puzzle game when I think it’s best described a logic puzzle. As someone who enjoys various puzzle games ranging from The Witness, Grim Fandango, TRI, or Thomas Was Alone, I cannot help but think this distinction is important. There are far more lateral-thinking puzzles based on chess-like preparation and understanding of the pieces you’re playing with rather than understanding the core mechanics and how to use them to solve a given situation/obstacle.

To describe this situation in a less convoluted way: “Puzzle Games” to me are comparable to Rubik’s cubes; they’re governed by rules, patterns and limitations that doesn’t require understanding the entire problem at once but how to shape the problem, gradually, by observation. “Logic Puzzles” are you given a Rubik cube in one formation and you’re given X amount of moves to solve the problem. The emphasis is placed on knowing how to manipulate the problem by an arbitrary obstacle meant to test your knowledge of the puzzle rather than your observations.  Although both instances use the same core mechanics, the skill you’re tested on is what defines the type of puzzle you are given. 

Puzzles in Snakebird range from both types of challenges, though the frequency of these types varies by each area of the game. Some levels will test you more so on understanding the level-gimmicks in “safe-environments” where you don’t have to meticulously plan three moves ahead, which I think these serve as the tutorials for new factors to consider (movable pieces, teleporters, etc.). Some levels attempt to focus your attention on the wonky physics of the Snakebirds like how they can float on fruit, propel one another with another Snakebird, move forward by changing their shape to cross a gap or how the positioning affects their movement. These latter mechanics are the bane of many people who didn’t get Snakebird because the first type of puzzles set different expectations, so often the player will be left with the reaction, “How was I supposed to figure out that!?”

However, what I think is perhaps more aggravating than the shift in focus of puzzles is the open-level design and how it interferes with the player learning the subtleties of Snakebirds.

[h1]Sometimes the Narrower Path Is Best to Travel[/h1]

Sometimes offering choice is to the detriment of the player if the open-level layout is not simple enough to guide confused players on the “intended” track of progress. Tutorials are not always the best solution but roadblocks with one intended method of success are far more aggravating for people to deal with if not handled properly.

Unlike in the open-world design of The Witness where there were guideposts from the boat’s map that pointed the player in the designated area of a puzzle type with symbols, Snakebird lacks any simple direction for the player. When you finish a level after the initial three, the game opens up various puzzles to prevent the player from getting stuck on one for an hour and to explore other types of puzzles before coming back to try again. There are even numbers associated with each level that would make one believe there is an intended path of progression, but often puzzles in a higher rating would be easier than lower-ranked puzzles or areas of the map would be far simpler to understand than other areas. Consistency is something the game severely lacks.

Part of the problem is personal preferences; I find level-gimmicks simpler than controlling two or three Snakebirds at once, and when the game does both I often found myself stuck. The other problem is rather a lack of scaling between puzzles that can ramp the previous challenge up or toss in something entirely different but building on the same idea. Asking for more puzzles is not the easiest solution but I think with Snakebird had the game provided better scaling between gimmicks, wonky physics and the amount of characters you control then the puzzles would be far easier to manage for people who don’t catch-on by a single puzzle. Repetition, especially in mastering a puzzle game with so many little things to learn, can be a blessing in disguise. 

[h1]Snakebirds: The Uroboros of Puzzle Purgatory[/h1]

At its core, I like Snakebirds as it’s a charming game with an idea that works surprisingly well when it’s understandable and not so nitpicky for solutions. Like the symbol of the snake it often feels like you’re wasting away in circles for endless trial-and-error until you flip the bird at the game or you realize the solution was staring at you all along with a simple change of perspectives.

31494825.review:
Fantastic puzzle game.

It feels involved and direct, as it's all based around movement of your characters (and the charming presentation helps). You're not solving abstract riddles, you're just helping snakebirds eat some fruit.

Despite that, it's incredibly hard, but also entirely fair. Easier levels introduce mechanics that you'll need to solve more difficult levels. For the majority of the game, you'll always have plenty of levels to pick from and try your wits out on, keeping you from feeling completely stuck, and helping you to come up with new ideas for possible solutions to puzzles you previously had no clue how to solve. Also, there's an undo button that can be used freely.

A wonderful side effect of the game is that it was also very relaxing and calming to me. Maybe it was the cheerful music, maybe it was all the snakebirds falling asleep when you wouldn't actively control them, or maybe it was just my poor brain slowly shutting off on the more difficult puzzles. But it was a really great experience playing the game in bed at night, until I couldn't keep my eyes open anymore. Video games as sleep aid. Who would've thought.

(PS: I solved 52 out of the 53 levels by myself, without a walkthrough. I could have totally solved that one level by myself too, if I had just been a little more patient with myself. If you play this, don't make my mistake. Don't spoil yourself. You can totally solve everything in here without any hints.)

29490834.review:
Snakebird est un bon jeu de puzzles qui suit les critères idéaux d'un jeu du genre, à savoir un concept facilement compréhensible et original, des graphismes et un univers très lisibles et apaisants, et des niveaux bien conçus d'apparence simple mais diaboliques.

Le [i]pitch[/i] du jeu est simple: Snake, le vieux concept de jeu vidéo où l'on dirige un serpent qui grandit chaque fois qu'il mange un fruit, plus la gravité. Dans chaque niveau, il s'agit de manger tous les fruits (s'il y en a) et de guider un ou plusieurs "snakebirds" vers le point de sortie.

En pratique, le jeu ressemble à un jeu de puzzles très classique, épuré, simple à contrôler, où l'on débloque l'accès aux puzzles suivants depuis une carte (ce qui permet de jouer dans le désordre en cas de blocage), mais autant le dire tout de suite: le jeu est [i]très, très dur,[/i] et s'adresse avant tout aux mordus du jeu de puzzles. On n'est pas du tout ici dans un gentil jeu qui se joue en "pilotage automatique" pour se détendre, mais dans un jeu où l'on peut rester longtemps bloqué dans un même niveau, et où il vaut donc mieux avoir une solide expérience du genre.

Cette difficulté est à la fois une qualité et un défaut: d'un côté, elle rend évidemment le jeu mémorable et intéressant (je me suis régalé), mais de l'autre, elle n'est pas ici très bien gérée, les puzzles n'étant pas très progressifs et certains principes pourtant fondamentaux étant parfois peu clairs. Le jeu donne aussi peu de prises: dès que l'on doit diriger plusieurs snakebirds ou que l'on doit pousser des blocs ou des congénères (ce qui est en réalité la mécanique la plus importante du jeu, plus que manger des fruits), la combinatoire devient très vite énorme et on se sent un peu perdu sans savoir par où commencer, le jeu pouvant assez facilement décourager ou frustrer les non-amateurs.

Au final, le jeu est bon, mais le concept n'est pas aussi original qu'on pourrait le croire (on pousse des blocs, avant tout), il y a assez peu de niveaux (une cinquantaine), l'univers et l'action manquent de personnalité, l'action est lente et un peu répétitive, et surtout, la difficulté n'est pas très bien maîtrisée.

Je recommande cependant Snakebird à petit prix pour les amateurs, même s'il est très loin des classiques comme Catrap, Fire 'n Ice ou Adventure of Lolo, ou, plus récemment et chez Nintendo, de [url=http://simbabbad.blogspot.fr/2013/09/mario-donkey-kong-minis-on-move-eshop.html]Mario and Donkey Kong: Minis on the Move[/url] ou de la série des [url=http://simbabbad.blogspot.fr/2013/08/pullblox-fallblox-eshop-3ds-nintendo.html]Pullblox[/url].

29412587.review:
I first played Snakebird back in 2015 when it first came out. I had heard it would be difficult, but I, even though I hadn't played many puzzle games, had played many logic puzzles for a few years and considered myself "good" at puzzles, and so thought this game wouldn't present much of a challenge.

How wrong I was.

Level 0? Easy. It teaches you how to move and what the goal of the game is. Eat all the fruits, exit the level via the rainbow spinny portal.

Level 1? Easy. It does introduce the undo button because almost everyone goes the obvious route (which is quite intended), and that gets them stuck. But the level is still innocent and easy; the developer laughs with you. "Don't worry man, it's just a small joke, you still got this."

Level 2? This is your first taste of hell. Many people who played this game on iOS rated the game 1 star and accused the developers of not playtesting their game well enough because they thought this level was unsolveable. But it *is* solvable, if only you take the time to reason through things logically, and make sure you don't repeat your mistakes. It's definitely brute-force-able if it comes down to it.

Many of my friends whom I've since introduced Snakebird to have gotten stuck on that level for quite a while. And I'll admit, I too got stuck on that level for a few minutes. You look at the puzzle and you think it's easy. Then you try to solve it and think it's impossible. Then you realize what you've been missing all along (it's not even a new game mechanic; it's just a possibility that you've for some reason excluded from consideration), and you feel humbled and stupid.

Despite its colourful aesthetic, this had been described as "The Dark Souls of Puzzle Games" before Stephen's Sausage Roll came out, and it soon became clear why at around level 6. I was in fact playing this game on stream. It took me a whole 15 minutes to figure out how to complete that level, even with a few subtle hints from a watcher. Sebastian, the employee at Noumenon Games who had designed that level, was actually watching me, and when I completed the level, I said "Right, you need to be given a raise, and fired simultaneously". Because that describes the sheer amount of awe, frustration, and admiration I have for the level's design. "Don't worry, it's not a small joke any more. Welcome to the cute fluffy hell of ripping your hair out at colourful snakebirds."

And it only gets harder from there. Later levels will require you to control two or more snakebirds, all of which must get to the exit; boxes that can be pushed around by your snakebirds, and portals that teleport your snakebirds. Often the snakebirds don't work the way you might naively think they do, but then you think about it a bit more and realize that that's how they've always worked. 

Even with all these mechanics, though, each level has a very narrow solution path (or on occasion, two different solution paths). Remember that undo button? Yeah, that has a reason. Without it, this game would be nigh-unplayable. The final level took me over a full hour to work out how to do, even with undos.

Yet at each minute I still felt I was making progress.

Because, like Elya Yelnats, who got stronger as the pig he was carrying got fatter, so did I get better at puzzles as the levels got harder. I was repeating my previous mistakes far less. I was realizing what I needed to do far faster. I was becoming one with the snakebirds, and one with the puzzle.

I came out of this trial by fruit far tougher than I ever was. This game honed my puzzle skills to a far stronger level. It showed me my place in the puzzle hierarchy by stomping me into the dirt, then it forced me to claw my way to the top with tooth and nail and pure brainpower. Without this, I would never have been able to complete any of Stephen's Sausage Roll.

If you're interested in becoming great at puzzles and you're at an intermediate or even strong beginner level, play this game. If you're an "expert" and you still haven't played this, you should definitely definitely play it. If you're below "strong beginner", I recommend that you stick to the easier games, like A Good Snowman Is Hard To Build, or Another Perspective.

Thank you, Snakebird. Thank you, Noumenon Games. Thank you for destroying me and thank you for making me better.

28713369.review:
类型：关卡式解谜
评分：3分（5分满分）
游戏方式：控制蛇鹈鸟（没错这细长玩意儿是鸟不是蛇，看嘴巴就知道，还有尾羽）移动到目的地即可。蛇鹈鸟的移动类似贪吃蛇，身体一直沿着之前的轨迹运动，也会吃水果长长。46小关+6星星关+1终极关=53关。

这部作品毫无疑问难度是比较高的，也有随着关卡推进不断出现新道具和玩法，但还是决定只给3分。
从前玩解谜，“难度”是我给游戏定级的最重要标度，但是实际上有许多游戏难度虽然高，玩起来却并不让人享受，没有激发起玩家无比迫切想去解开谜题的斗志。解谜游戏好歹是由“解谜”和“游戏”两个部分组成，如果游戏性不好，怎么能说它是个好游戏呢。

回到本作本身，一个典型的关卡游戏，画面卡通，音乐欢快，难度优秀。之所以让只给3分，是因为游戏机制太简单单调了，鸟顶来顶去扭来扭去基本就是玩法核心了，想来也许我是嫌弃一切可以在移动端上蹲厕所就能玩的游戏被放到电脑上吧。
和本作同为高难度关卡解谜的Stephen's Sausage Roll相反我就很推崇，想来一方面是香肠卷难度更有挑战性，一方面就是游戏性、关卡分类、关卡递进方面更有智慧。
总结起来，本作适合喜爱解谜和挑战自己的人，不适合没耐心的人。

[b]An incredibly tough tile-based puzzle game.[/b]
The art style & theme are things you'd see on a mobile game not at all giving the impression that the game won't be at all difficult but as the Steam store page says it's deceptively challenging.

There are a total of 53 stages, including the tutorial & extra stages, and more unlock as you keep completing stages. There's no particular order you have to do them in as the available stages are shown to you on a world map so you can basically go to another puzzle even if you've already started one. Stages don't necessarily get harder as you progress either so if say you've been stuck on one puzzle for a while you can hold that off for the time being and move on to another.

The gist of the gameplay is that you solve puzzles using a Snakebird thing with movements like in that old game, Snake.
The tutorial stage will teach you how to play the game and the first few numbered stages after will basically teach you how the physics of the game work through your own experience. After all that the game will start to become noticeably difficult as the rest of the game expects you to basically be an expert in the mechanics and then some as the stages are designed to have you needing to do a a lot of figurative zigs and zags with the solutions to the puzzles. It can get incredibly frustrating with that case possibly encouraging more trial & error scenarios than thought-out ones. There's even an "Undo" option that lets you constantly undo the last move you just did all the way from when the puzzle started in case you made a mistake. Later stages will introduce a few new mechanics you'll have to work with.

It ain't bad for something with graphics that look like they're better off in the mobile market.

28023752.review:
"Snakebird is an elegant puzzle game."

This game is great because it's clear that each level was designed with a specific goal in mind that in order to accomplish, you must realize a new facet of the deep mechanics that make up the game. The mechanics are actually simple, but together they create some very deep interactions that you will need to fully grasp in order to complete the more challenging later puzzles.

However, Snakebird does not start off overwhelming and the basic mechanics are introduced gradually in the first few levels with a nice difficulty curve. Paying close attention to the "how" and "why" of the solutions of these early puzzles will be invaluable for finding the solutions to future puzzles.

Levels are spaced across a world map with each biome having its own mechanical theme or new puzzle object to interact with in addition to the snakebirds. The world map is laid out in such a way that multiple levels can possibly unlock from completing the previous one. This is incredibly helpful in case you get stuck so that you can go try a different puzzle in the meantime and return to the first one later with a new perspective. 

Each puzzle itself is elegant and you rarely, if ever, NOT use everything in a level. Everything involved in a puzzle can be seen on a single screen at all times and there is nothing included to obfuscate the solution like extra objects to interact with that you don't need. There is a clear starting point with only a few pieces to work with, but the process to the goal remains interesting. If you get stuck on a puzzle, there is usually enough space in the level to move the snakebirds around to help generate ideas to yourself about what to do next. Otherwise, undoing your moves or resetting the puzzle altogether is just a push of a button away. It helps to be able to play around with the "puzzle pieces" that you're given to reach an ah-ha moment that gives you a new strategy to follow. Some levels will restrict your movement options quite a bit from the start, so deduction will likely play a bigger role in these puzzles.

The aesthetic charm and polish of Snakebird shouldn't be overlooked either. The colorful environments, relaxing music, and expressive faces of the snakebirds all create a pleasant atmosphere to soothe any pent-up frustration that you may experience while being unable to eat that distant fruit without falling to your demise in the briny sea below! There are also plenty of environmental doodads to click and mouse over should your mind wander.

Anytime I completed a level I had spent a lot of time on, I actually slowly clapped as the little fireworks went off in-game. I clapped not for myself, but for how brilliant the designers/developers were for creating the level!

I got to hand it to Noumenon Games for making such a clever title! o//

**Snakebird has made me think in ways I have not thought before, so for that, I nominate it for Steam's "WHOOOAAAAAAA, DUDE!" Award!**

25158781.review:
Looks so adorable and polished that you'd think it'd be another Angry Birds type puzzle game that you can just turn off your brain and enjoy. 

But in reality, it's a brain-punchingly hard puzzle game. Each puzzle introduces some new element, or new arrangement of elements, and you have to figure out the perfect technique to interact with it. You can easily spend half an hour just fiddling the birds around until you have a breakthrough and realize that you have to set one bird up [i]just so[/i], so that it can catch a falling block without the bird becoming trapped or unsaveable. Luckily, after the first few levels you can start skipping over levels, so if you don't reach a breakthrough you can just come back to it later. And when you finally complete a particularly tricky one, it really feels like you've accomplished something!

Also, the snakebirds make very silly noises that literally had me giggling aloud while playing.

25105766.review:
Snakebird is, despite its colourful appearance and charm, one of the hardest puzzle games on Steam, if not one of the hardest games.

I'm going to start this review by telling you to watch the first trailer provided for this game, as it explains the basic mechanics better than any text can do, and also highlights how incredibly complex such a simple game mechanic can be.

In terms of production quality, Snakebird is absolutely fantastic. The art is done [url=http://noumenongames.com/the-art-of-snakebird/]with an incredible attention to detail[/url] and perfectly reflects the outward simplicity but underlying complexity of the puzzles themselves. Every object in the environment is meticulously designed and work together perfectly to create a cohesive minimalist design.

The music is done by Carl Karjalainen, and isn't too eye-catching (ear-catching?) - but this is probably a good thing, as if you're planning on completing Snakebird you're going to hear all of the tracks a [i]lot[/i] of times. 

But these are mostly besides the point - I don't know many people who buy a puzzle game for its soundtrack, so you're probably reading the reviews to find out what the puzzles are like. To be extremely blunt: if you don't enjoy feeling stupid, don't buy this game. It is INCREDIBLY difficult, to the point where even 10 levels in (out of slightly more than 50) it's already harder than the final levels of most other popular puzzle games. By the mid-game each step requires 50 steps of planning ahead to make sure you're not going to move yourself into a corner, and there's virtually no room for error with nearly every puzzle requiring nearly exact moves to complete it correctly.

It should be noted that this difficulty is [b]NOT[/b] arbitrary or forced. The developers aren't making deliberately obtuse or tedious puzzles just to drag out the runtime, and every single puzzle makes complete sense once you work it out, using the relatively limited set of features in extremely clever ways.

Personally, I think that this game is fantastic, both in its production quality and in its fiendish difficulty, but it's definitely not for everybody. You have to absolutely love difficult puzzles to enjoy this game, and you'll get frustrated extremely quickly if you aren't used to that kind of challenge. If you are, though, there's basically no better option for training mental acuity.

24821458.review:
I got stuck. I almost made a refund because of the incorrect claims in the negative reviews. Then I started quickly solving the puzzles that seemed "impossible"... and it turned out they are very easy once you understand what you're actually doing. 
So I decided to help anyone who's on the fence and has read the negative reviews.

- It's not true that the game doesn't slowly introduce you to the basics
- It's not true that the game doesn't have different locations with different gameplay themes

- IT IS true, that the game gets difficult very, very quick
- IT IS true, that if you believe that you are smart, and in reality you're not, the game will crush you without mercy

- It is not true that the puzzles are complex, but random. No, they are very meaningful, but if you're not smart enough, you won't be able to understand the meaningful pattern behind the solution, even if someone shows it to you. Just like any other difficult logic game, you have to visualize what you want, your final goal, and what prevents you from getting there, but here you also have to rely on your spacial reasoning and that's differently developed in different people. 

There's a risk that the game may not be for you. Have you finished "English Country Tune" or "Stephen's Sausage Roll"? What about the hardest secret levels in "Sokobond"? Was the last level of "Open Doors 2" relatively easy for you? What about any Alan Hazelden game, like "Boxes love boxing gloves"? You didn't need a walkthrough to get through "The Witness", did you? If the answer to any of these questions is "Yes", than go ahead. If not, try the demo. (There is a demo, even if it's not on Steam). And don't give up immediately. Give it time. Good luck.

24386413.review:
[b][i]Snakebird[/i] is an absolutely fabulous puzzle game.[/b] It's an unexpected candidate, but in my opinion right up there with [i]Braid[/i] and [i]Portal[/i]. That being said, refer to the Downsides and Caveats below for some things to keep in mind in deciding if you specifically will like it.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The mechanics are very simple and (with one or two exceptions) almost completely self-explanatory. There are only a finite number of possible moves at any given position. Yet, from level two or three, you will likely get pretty stuck. Moreover, you will be absolutely baffled at how you got stuck on such a clearly simple level: you know an easy solution must exist, and it's going to be completely obvious in hindsight. (If you don't believe me on this, just watch TotalBiscuit struggle with it on Youtube. He spends 7.5 very painful minutes on level 2. He then spends 6.5 additional painful minutes on level 3 before giving up.)

So begins a series of excellent, completely solvable, but extremely difficult puzzles. You are lucky if you don't get stuck on almost all of them. They aren't tedious or just a matter of brute force. Rather, as with all of the best puzzle games, you must piece together techniques and strategies you have learned in previous levels to get you through more difficult ones. Each level involves careful planning: working backwards, figuring out what sequences of subgoals might get you to the end, and using process of elimination to rule out impossible sequences until you find one that works. Many levels [i]look[/i] impossible and (another aspect of all great puzzle games) you will feel like a genius when you solve them.

[h1]Playtime[/h1]

There are over 50 puzzles (I won't say exactly how many to avoid a minor spoiler); I got about 16 hours of playtime although of course it will be more or less depending on how quickly you solve them. That's a little under 20 minutes a puzzle, on average, but the hardest ones must have taken me close to an hour each.

Definitely worth it for $7 in my opinion, although I got the game for much less in a humble bundle. Note, however, that you can get full game as a mobile app for $4.71 (on Android; probably similar on iphone) if you want to save money that way, and don't mind playing it on a phone.

[h1]Downsides and Caveats[/h1]

[list]
[*] [b]Aside from the puzzles themselves and the cute graphics and animations there is very little else to this game.[/b] For instance, there is no story at all. To enjoy the game you must be the kind of person who enjoys puzzles for their own sake. That being said, the graphics and clickable background and music are all very pleasant.

[*] [b]This game is very, very difficult.[/b] As such, it is not for everyone. You will get stuck; often there's only one very particular way to solve a puzzle and you have to think through things methodically to find it. When you get stuck, you will also often have no option other than to switch to a different level and come back later. If you are easily frustrated, that's a downside to getting this game.

[*] Along the lines of the above, [b]there are no hints![/b] You have to beat every level to complete the game. If you get [i]really[/i] stuck you can always look up a solution online, but I don't recommend it because it will leave you feeling annoyed with the game in the end since you weren't able to figure it out.

[*] Finally, a very minor point: using the mouse to control the snakebird is not great, so just use the keyboard. (Mouse is still good for panning though.)

[/list]

24202292.review:
Well, see what comes out of fervently wishing for something. I've loved the indie puzzle revolution of recent years, I only wished for more difficult, more challenging puzzles, because it was really celebration time if a game produced at least a few levels that made your neurons sweat a little. And now enter Snakebird, a cute, nice-looking little game, which is really a ruthless killer of a puzzle game in candy-flavoured disguise.
Snakebird wants you to collect all the fruits on a level and proceding to the exit with every one of your characters. Eating a fruit grows your snakebird with one unit, gravity works in the game, some levels provide you with simple items to help your progress, while the environment sometimes wants to kill you. There. That's it, really - and a collection of really, really tough levels, which manage to be hard without being unfair.

Snakebird is easily the best (non-construction) puzzle game I've played in a long while - I bow before the greatness of the people who designed its levels. For those who are looking for a serious brainy challenge - highly recommended.

24134207.review:
My problem with this game lies in the extreme narrowness of its solutions, despite the apparent breadth of ways to approach each puzzle. What I mean by this is that it's not enough to solve a part of a puzzle, you have to solve it by making the exact moves the developers envisioned, otherwise the next part of the puzzle will likely be unsolveable, however as you have no way of knowing this, hours of frustration await.

I consider myself a puzzle game enthusiast (I'm particularly fond of the masterful works put out by Zachtronics) and the difficulty in Snakebird is beyond anything I could have imagined. I note that most of the positive reviews here have less than 2 hours of play time and if I'd done a write up after the first dozen puzzles this review would likely be amongst them, however I don't review games unless I've finished them or have lost interest. Sadly, Snakebird falls into the latter category.

It's not a bad game, but when I'm railroaded into solving a puzzle from one particular angle, despite the illusion of a plurality of angles being available, I feel that the game is not being fair.

I'm actually on the fence about this one, cause the game is so hard.  But it has such hilarious visuals that I just can't frown at it.

So, should a game be rated down because it's "too hard"?  Well, generally I'd say no.  But this game doesn't give you much help in learning the ropes.  The developers must have assumed that the extremely simple base mechanic meant that nobody would need help mastering it, I guess.  

After a couple of moderately challenging levels you come to puzzles that are mind-bendingly difficult, with only one solution, that seem impossible.  Who knows, they could be impossible, I couldn't figure them out.  It isn't so thrilling that I wanted to spend the time to figure them out, either.

But maybe that's what you need.  Maybe you need to meet the mind-bendingly challenging puzzle, and prove that you're able to bend your mind that far.

So, I recommend this game to you, masochists and geniuses.  And, anyone who just loves the idea of a birdsnake... those things are hilarious.

23835338.review:
[h1] The cute little devil of puzzle-games [/h1]

I usually don't write reviews, but this little gem definitely deserves one!

Snakebird is a puzzle game. Your goal is to collect all fruits to unlock the exit of the stage. If a Snakebird collects a fruit, it gains +1 length (you get a bigger buttock.. kind of). The concept is simple, but don't let this fact deceive you! The difficulty rises extremly steep with each level and level-section.
The game-world is made of different level-sections. In each one the game gets an extra aspect, like: use a box, a teleporter or some platforms to reach your goal. I know.. it actually sounds like it's making the whole thing easier, but.. well.. not really.
The music is nice & relaxing and the artstyle is very cute.

[b] Gameplay: [/b] good (4/5)
[b] Music: [/b] good (4/5)
[b] Artstyle: [/b] good (4/5)
[b] Difficulty: [/b] very hard (5/5)
[b] Fairness: [/b] balanced/not unfair (5/5)

If your into puzzle games, like to complete some challenges (do yourself a favor and don't cheat) and got some time to spare (some puzzles take their time), than this is your game! It is definetly worth the price, so give make an effort and buy it. :)

23806390.review:
Snakebird is one of those rare games that feels absolutely solid.  Presentation is great.  Controls are great.  Difficulty is superbly devious.

It seems simple:  Navigate all the snakebirds on the screen, to the rainbow portal, eating all fruit on the level in the process.   But you will learn to hate gravity.

The graphics and solid controls takes one back to Super Nintendo days and are a joy to look at.

But the heart of this game is the superb puzzles.  53 levels to complete in total.  Millions of hair strands to remove from your head in the process.

No two levels are the same and yet, sometimes you solve a puzzle purely on luck.  Try to do the same level a second time and you have no clue how you completed it the first time...

Even though most of the puzzles are super hard, stick with it.  Figuring out a level feels extremely satisfying and most of the time you learn something that will help in the coming levels.

Greatly recommended for anybody up for a serious challenge.

This makes it both frustrating and not frustrating, because at least I don't feel totally clueless most of the time.

It's a very neat concept, but I really can't recommend it but to the most hardcore puzzle fanatics. Reason: it gets too hard WAY too fast. And that's really a missed opportunity, as the concept is very interesting. But this game doesn't mess around and requires perfect execution almost from the get-go. There is no "here are a few easy levels but with some stars hidden in them if you play them really well", a few filler levels that let you get used to shaping into different positions to reach something or a hint system. That the game resets you back to just before you died also gets annoying fast, as at that point you usually have no choice but to restart (why isn't that the default?).

I can't say much of later levels, but the early ones had pretty unintuitive solutions to them either. I never had a "oooh, so THAT was what I was doing wrong!" moment when I looked up an answer. Rather, I felt that the only way to beat this game was to program something to just go with every possible combination of movements and let it run for some hours. Game of the year for 2015 (for me, anyways).

Ranks up there with English Country Tune.  Many puzzles simply look impossible upon initial assessment.  The mechanics of the game may initially feel counterintuitive [spoiler](eg. snakebirds can stand on fruit floating in mid-air)[/spoiler], but are consistent and fair. 23644571.review:
If you're a puzzle game enthusiast looking for a new and unique challenge, this game will make you very happy. 

It is:

SMART: The levels are designed to make you discover the intricacies of the game's mechanics. As the trailer suggests, the levels are often set up to suggest an initial strategy that ends up not working, giving way to a seemingly insurmountable barrier, and the fun lies in finding the trick that gets you past it.

SUCCINCT: In some 50 levels a number of mechanics are introduced (multiple snakebirds, pushable blocks, warps) that keep things fun and new. None of the levels seem redundant- I really found myself learning something new in each level.

DAMN CUTE: And the cuteness correlates a bit with the game's functionality. When a snakebird's head is moved next to a spike, it gets nervous. Next to a fruit, it looks happy and excited. The pastel-children's-book visual style, along with fun synth music and sound effects, work very well. Bravo. 

Comparison: This has a similar genius to Stephen Lavelle's commercial games (English Country Tune, Stephen's Sausage Roll). If you're a fan of those, you'll love this (and vice versa).

PWYW for this as part of the current Humble Indie Bundle (until Tuesday 6/21 midday), but honestly this gem is a steal at full price.

SNAKEBIRD is a game that is supposedly about eating FRUIT but is really about working out how to reach the RAINBOW PORTAL at the end of each map by working out how to navigate the level. Many levels don't even have FRUIT. The gameplay is [i]essentially[/i] snake as a platformer with an endgoal.
SNAKEBIRD remains fun despite repetition like many simple games such as snake and mitosis. It's relatively challenging, and not particularly frustrating even when the puzzles are complicated due to the UNLIMITED UNDO FUNCTION. The music is outright painful after a certain period and you should probably listen to something else while you play.

On the subject of kids, most of the levels require a bit of forward thinking and trial-and-error. It's a polished little game that would be great for children that like the general experience of soft-cornered gameplay and aren't overly keen on fighting, racing or sports games. It vaguely involves fractions and division since the specific length of the snake in numerical terms needs to be considered on many of the levels.

N.B. [spoiler]Despite the blurb, you never get to actually find out how long a SNAKEBIRD can become when it has as much FRUIT as it could ask for.[/spoiler]

21558685.review:
I've never written a review of a game before, but Snakebird is so criminally underappreciated I have to make an exception.

The mechanics of Snakebird are very simple. There isn't a great way to explain them with words, but if you watch the video, you'll see the core idea very quickly - it's like the old-school game Snake, except our dear snakebirds are subject to gravity. There are a couple twists on this formula, but they are also very intuitive. The focus is not on throwing mechanics at you, but on puzzles that force you to push those mechanics to their limits.

This is the hardest puzzle game I've ever played. Not because it's full of cheap tricks, or because of randomness (a la Candy Crush), or because it's complicated - the puzzles are (mostly) fair, they're just brutally hard. It's the Dark Souls of puzzle games. If that sounds good to you, this game is for you!

Also, although the game is difficult, it never gets too frustrating, because once you solve the first few puzzles, you'll have a bunch of puzzles unlocked at any given time. Which means you can always bang your head against another wall. Plus, the art is delightful! My favorite part is the expressions of the snakebirds. When you leave them hanging next to spikes, their eyes are terrified and imploring; when you leave them next to fruit, they gaze at it desirously; and the rest of the time, they look at you like they're too cool to be in this puzzle. It's more endearing than it sounds.

I hope the creators of this game come out with many more like it!

20433024.review:
Out of all the games I played in 2015 starring elongated narcoleptic birds, Snakebird is my favorite.

The premise is pretty straightforward: Steer your snakebird toward the exit.

Like in the classic Snake game, your snakebird's head will move in the direction you choose, its tail following behind. If your snakebird eats a piece of fruit, its tail will grow one segment longer.

Unlike classic Snake, your snakebirds are not self-driving, they are affected by gravity, and there are sometimes several to control within a single level.

If there is fruit in a level, you must collect it all to unlock the exit. In addition, you must guide ALL of a level's snakebirds to the exit, not just one. This might not sound like that big of an obstacle until you realize that some levels require your snakebirds to climb on each other to advance.

These are not easy puzzles. There are a few basic stages to ease you into the rules, but then you're thrown right into the heavy stuff. Thankfully, the game is not purely linear. When you solve one level, the levels adjecent on the world map will be unlocked, regardless of how they are numbered. This is a feature that I worry will be overlooked by a lot of people, and more puzzle games would do well to incorporate it. I couldn't tell you how many times I got frustrated on a puzzle, then left to play a different puzzle, and returned later with success.

Another great feature: the game remembers every move you make on a given attempt, so instead of having to restart a stage every time you fall offscreen or land on spikes or get yourself trapped, you can hit Undo as many times as you like.

There are multiple methods of controlling your snakebirds, but my personal recommendation is the skip the mouse during puzzles and use arrow keys to move, Tab to switch between snakebirds, and Backspace to undo.

If you're looking for a timewaster, you might not have a very good time with this one. If you're looking for actually difficult actual puzzles that require thought and planning, you should strongly consider Snakebird.

Grapes / 10

19401567.review:
Snakebird is a PC exclusive (OSX/LIN as well) puzzle games about cute birds shaped like snakes in a cheery, bright world. Both the art style and the score of the game evoke a very touching, peaceful, and beautifully innocent atmosphere.

However, that is nothing but a lie that is surface deep. Once you pass the first few levels which guide you through the mechanics, you are put in a situation where the world map begins to branch out.


It's adorable, isn't it? It's large, but it evokes a very friendly, inviting atmosphere. At first look, this is the kind of game you'd expect to see on your child's iPad or iPod touch, right?

Wrong again. This is just the selection of which of the 9 circles of Hell you'd like to traverse through first is.

The mechanics are fairly simple! You control Snakebirds, moving them around, getting fruit and moving obstacles. Sometimes you get one Snakebird, sometimes you get a few and you have to use them together as teamwork to reach the goal. Once all the fruit is collected, each Snakebird has to get through the colourful portal that opens up to leave the level. Thankfully, there is a button that is an equivalence to a "ctrl+z", undoing your last move.


You will make the Snakebirds die. They will literally quiver in fear as they stare down a pitfall, or a spiked block, or spikes in general. If another Snakebird is in danger, and you switch to your other Snakebird, he will glare you down with the force of a thousand suns. A look full of hate.

The first time I bought this game, I bought it full price. I played it for a while, before nearly tearing my hair out in frustration. I enjoyed a solid 8 hours of gameplay during a week where I had next to no consistent internet - and I hadn't downloaded many other of my games to my new harddrive. By the time I had internet back up reliably, I immediately refunded it. Snakebird had beaten me, beaten me into a bloody pulp. I 3-stock Contra with ease. I've had no issues toppling Miyazaki and co.'s Souls games, nor Bloodborne. Hardcore endgame raiding in MMOs? Been there, done that. Rhythm games? Bring 'em on, I got this. Shmups? I can do it, pass me the arcade stick. Fighting games? I'm slightly better than the average Joe.

Snakebird? Snakebird broke me.

But I just bought it again in the Steam sale! I mean, it's half off, and I've spent time away from it. Maybe the difficulty was routed in me being frustrated by silly, easy puzzles? 

Nope. 

Snakebird was, and continues to be, ballbustingly hard. I'm tearing my hair out here. Once I finally think I have the level beaten, I realize that there is no way for me to get both of my Snakebirds to the portal, or I've trapped myself to a point where I can't get that last piece of fruit so easily...

Anyways, I'm going back to playing Snakebird until I have a stroke or brain hemorrhage. You should play it too.

18027528.review:
This is one of those games that went under my radar for some time, even going on my "not interested" list, as most absurd-sounding-or-looking games often do ("Snakebird"?? Really?).  That is, it went under my radar until I saw a fairly well-known Youtuber try and fail repeatedly to solve one of the first few levels, while I thought about how simple the solution was, and that was that.  I bought the game the next time I jumped on Steam.  Then, just to prove my puzzling prowess, I installed it immediately and sped through the first several levels and then almost as quickly ran into the spiking difficulty curve.

Yes, this game is unabashedly hard, and I have since found myself yelling "How is that even possible?" at my computer more than once.  However, in today's world, where most puzzles in games can be solved by something as simple as a greedy algorithm or were directly pulled out of one of Sam Loyd's puzzle books, having an original puzzle game of this difficulty is actually quite the treat.  The game unlocks new levels in a nonlinear fashion, so when you get stuck in one puzzle, you can jump to another and work on it, and every so often you'll notice something in one puzzle which leads you to that "eureka!" moment in which the solution to THAT ONE LEVEL you've been stuck on for HOURS comes to you!

The level design itself is simple but good enough.  You move within a discrete 2D grid on the screen, so there's never any confusion about hit boxes of spikes and ledges.  If you fall, it is always obvious why you fell, at least in retrospect, and you can rewind any move if you accidentally move in the wrong direction after setting up a difficult solution.  Additionally, the fact that you can rewind any number of moves means that you don't have to restart the level after every mistake, which I feel is a mistake too many developers make when designing puzzles.

Unless one materializes further into the game, however, this game does not have any real storyline, so if you're someone who is likely to look up the solutions online at the first sign of difficulty, I'd give this game a pass, as there doesn't seem to be anything beyond the joy of solving difficult puzzles here.  On the other hand, if your idea of a good puzzle game is running into a seemingly impossible puzzle, leaving it for a while, and then coming back after you think of another way to attempt solving the puzzle... then I'd wonder which pre-internet time period you're from, but then I'd say you should play Snakebird.

17635833.review:
Snakebird is a difficult puzzle game with simple mechanics. What makes the game so challenging is how well thought out all of the puzzles are. This game is not for everyone, but anyone who wants a challenging puzzle game will surely be pleased with Snakebird.

Unfortunately, Snakebird has been widely ignored by the press. The game appears to be a casual game for children to play from its screenshots. But if a child were to complete this he/she would need a serious amount of persistence and brain power. This game is not designed for children, but some may enjoy it.

Each area in Snakebird introduces new mechanics that serve well for making a variety of different puzzles. Every puzzle feels very unique and the gameplay always feels fresh. If you are stuck on a level, go on to a different one and come back to it. Snakebird will not only test your puzzle skills but also your persistance. People who are very impatient will struggle to finish this game.

Forget about the fancy graphics and mindless entertainment that a lot of next-gen games are giving nowadays. Snakebird forces whoever plays it to think and provides a good challenge for those who enjoy puzzles. Based on the design of all of the levels, I can tell that a lot of time and thought went into all of the puzzles. The creators of Snakebird are ingenius and deserve more attention than they have been given.

The difficulty ramps up quickly, so expect to take breaks when you get frustrated. The game does a good job of making you feel that you've learned something with each level, which I really appreciate. It's surprising just how many interesting puzzles arise from the simple mechanics. I really liked this puzzle game and you probably will too.

Edit: it looks like some players have concluded that the puzzles in ths game can't be solved except with brute force. I would strongly recommend not using brute force in this game. Yes, it is a simple grid based puzzle and so backtracking algorithms will eventually yeld solutions, but at the cost of enjoyng the game or learning from it. If you get so frustrated that you want to just brute force a level, take a break and let the puzzle percolate in your subconcious for a bit. I promise you that brute force is not a major part of solving the puzzles.

Finally, an exercise: prove that solvability of a Snakebird level is NP-hard (no portals!).

17229297.review:
I'm giving this game a positive review, even though I didn't really enjoy it.

The thing is, it's a lot harder than the cutesy graphics suggest. You can't just muddle through the puzzles; there's usually a single specific series of moves needed to win, and one wrong move at any point will block you. It's got move-by-move undo all the way back to the beginning of the level, so it's not hard to roll back once you realize your mistake, but I was looking for a casual puzzler, not a hardcore brain-twister.

On the other hand, if you like hardcore brain-twisters, then this one is fantastic, and the presentation is beautifully polished. It's the sort of thing you'll enjoy, if you enjoy this sort of thing.

16236869.review:
A wonderful game!

I saw this a few days ago on Youtube, and had bought it before the video was even 5 minutes in. The presentation oozes charm, and the core mechanic of combining the classic Snake with a variation on traditional Klotski puzzles intrigued me no end.

I was not disappinted! This may very well be the most enjoyable puzzle game I've ever played. You're eased in gently for the first few levels, but the difficulty increases very quickly. Mercifully the game does let up now and then, giving you a couple of easier levels after introducing a new mechanic, such as moveable blocks and portals. Also, while the stages are numbered sequentially, you are not forced to play them as such, so if one particular puzzle is giving you a headache you can move on and come back to it at another time.

The later levels pose a formidable challenge, and a few took me close to an hour each to figure out. It never feels cheap however - while difficult, the puzzles are fair and after each mistake, I usually felt one step closer to finding the solution. With puzzles such as the aformentioned Klotski, I find my interest wanes and I eventually turn to a guide, but Snakebird engaged me in such a way that I was compelled to persevere, and the feeling of satisifaction at finally cracking some of the trickier stages was palpable.

Snakebird is a prime example of how to do Indie games well. By focussing on one relatively simple core mechanic, Noumenon have been able to craft a finely honed gameplay experience, with far more complexity than you might expect. The delightful presentation and adorable characters only serve to enhance the experience even further.

Highly recommended!

I admit defeat. Don't get me wrong, the game is exceptionally well done. It looks beautiful and the game mechanics are extremely smart and intuitive.

But it is unbelievably hard. I have played Braid, The Talos Principle or The Swapper before and never really got stuck. Those games teach you basic principles and then present you with bigger problems where you can use your new knowledge. Not so Snakebird. Every level is a random puzzle without any connection to the one before. There is no communication happening between the developers and the player. Unfortunately, when this silent communication happens it is when I love puzzle games the most.

I mean, anyone can come up with exceptionally hard puzzles. I could present you with a random chess board and ask you to show me the least number of moves in order to get to that same chess board configuration. There, you have a hard puzzle game. Unfortunately, the only way to solve it is to know the movement rules of each figure and then think it backwards, keeping infinitely complex decision trees in mind.

A Rubik's Cube is the same and I think this is the best analogy. This game feels (and looks) very much like a Rubik's Cube.

I made it to level 15 without cheating. After that, I had to look up the solutions for most maps on Youtube. At level 25 I gave up.

The thing is, I don't even know how to improve the game. It is a quite perfect game. It just doesn't invoke any fun for me.

16003385.review:
Watch our full review on Steam Punks here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=axdAvs3hngQ

The Snakebirds are hungry and want their fruit! By combining everybody’s favourite Nokia game and one of the weirdest looking necks on an animal, Noumenon Games released an unexpectedly thoughtful 2D puzzler that’s receiving criminally low attention. While not everyone might want to trade their scales for feathers, it’s worth finding out why this indie title is even greater than the old cell phone sensation.

On a first glance Snakebird is deceptively simple, with soft bright colours and shapes giving the game its child-like innocence. Your perception is corrected quickly however, with puzzle designs that are extraordinarily tight and meticulous, and often only have one way to be solved. The mechanics are simple; there’s no real tutorial because the pick-up and play style and the game’s method of subtle teaching doesn’t need it. The objective in each stage is to collect every piece of fruit before successfully reaching the goal portal. Just as in the classic game of Snake each fruit you eat adds an extra unit of length, a mechanic that makes some levels an experiment in discovering which fruit should be eaten first. Players can move in a forward direction with only immediate turns available to them, turning what seems to be a stage that can be easily traversed into an abstract thought exercise. You’ll quickly run into a problem where you can’t back out, it starts to sink in that there’s a lot more to this title. Levels are precisely crafted, there’s no wasted space and everything presented has been a contemplated part of the puzzle. Stages begin with a single Snakebird, but soon players are asked to manage 2 or three at a time, quickly adding layers to the challenge. Later on moveable blocks become staples to puzzles as well, and being able to handle using these objects to interact together effectively is what’s key to success.

For the amount it stumps you the game hardly induces a serious level of frustration, and when it does it’s often just enough to motivate you to attempt a different tactic. Answers often require out of the box approaches; there’s almost a paradoxical feel to many of the game’s solutions. You’ll discover what needs to be accomplished and spend 10 minutes exploring every way why that’s impossible, only to eventually arrive at a moment where the entire puzzle makes sense. It’s about discovery in little ways, and learning how to test every theory your mind can toss at a problem and then some. Despite the sometimes impossible-feeling difficulty progression never really feels too far away. Upon death you’re replaced where you were just before your last move, and the always available quick reverse option to undo any mistakes you’ve made is a great design choice to make the player want to experiment as much as possible without feeling punished.

The classic world map layout is a great way to present non-linear stage progression; more skilled players can attempt harder levels after only completing a handful, but most will likely stick to the beaten path and enjoy the gradual rise in difficulty through the well thought-out introductions to new concepts. You’ll start to learn optimal movement patterns and ways to contort your birds just through design and ramping complexity. It’s refreshing how much credit the game gives to the player’s intelligence; puzzles are created in a way as to tempt you into all sorts of traps, but it has enough sense to let you work out what exactly needs to be done about a situation. There’s absolutely no fat to weigh anything down either. A great deal of care has been taken in presenting what’s vital in each stage without distraction, allowing each player to absorb every idea at their own pace. With such simplicity, it manages to teach complex ideas without uttering a word.

There’s a stark contrast between the feelings brought out by gameplay and what’s experienced through the game’s visual tone. The simple but elegant aesthetic relaxes you even on long sittings of little progress. The fine attention to detail is there too; there are adorable facial expressions on the birds to show their excitement or fear, and various clickable objects to randomly interact with. The multiple control setups allows for great ease of access. Players can engage through keyboard, controller, or even use the mouse to drag Snakebirds around. This control scheme leads us to believe that it wouldn’t be much of a stretch to see this game on the mobile market, and it would be a magnificent addition.

On the surface it might even look like a game for children, but Snakebird is far from it. With its excruciating difficulty and great feeling of reward upon completion, it deserves to be regarded among more well-known complex indie puzzlers. If you’re ever up for some serious low cost brain-bending just try to feed the Snakebirds.
SCORE: 8.4

15903919.review:
Have you seen the trailers? Why are you still not playing this game?

[i]Snakebird[/i] is a pure grid-based puzzle game. Every key press responds to one action. You can undo any number of steps.

You control one snake at a time. You can move it like in the popular game [i]Snake[/i], and eat fruit as well. But what is this? The game takes action in a side view, so the snakes fall like in [i]Tetris[/i]! The "snake" remains rigid, never rotates, and falls down only if there is nothing below it. The "bird" part, I suppose, refers to the fact that the creatures can slightly lift off the ground, only to fall afterwards.

And there is not much more to explain. This concept gives birth to a vast amount of combinations and gameplay possibilities, especially if there are multiple snakes! Of course, some additional gameplay concepts are present, all very natural and intuitive. Spikes, movable blocks, portals and whatnot. Even the level exit portal acts as a gameplay element, because losing a snake often renders the level unsolvable for the other snakes.

The graphics are immaculate. Don't be fooled by the cuteness, though. The game is very, very difficult. Not much to do here for (most) kids.
The soundtrack never gets boring.

It may be "a little" early, but I would dare call this the puzzle game of the year.

★★★★★★★★★☆

15894001.review:
This game's core mechanic - moving around snakes - is amazingly intuitive. It is a very solid puzzle game - and it's a good puzzle game, not just a good game. I know I wanted a puzzle game that wasn't deceptive towards the player and this game does just that - that's why it's a good puzzle game, and not simply a good game.

Snakebird is a difficult puzzle game. Use the Steam achievements to check out the completion rate of this game - that was an instant-buy for me. The art style happens to work wonders to keep players from the verge of frustration. Despite it looking like a children's puzzle game from the outset, it quickly ramps up and its audience changes drastically.

The game itself has incredibly varied graphics and mechanics, which helps for keeping your mindset changing throughout levels. Despite being abstract, it still manages to be immersive with a pleasant art style and great sound design to go with it. The level progression allows you to visit several individual levels at one point in the game, so a spike in difficulty in one level will not prevent you from playing the rest of the game.

The only flaws I could recall in the game are that your level progress does not get individually saved (however, if you quit the game during a level, it will save that, but only that). Another "flaw" could be the lack of a hint system, but such a feature would be a detraction from the main selling point of the game's challenge. The sound and music also lack sliders to change their percentage.

One word of note: your snake can stand on the fruits, just like any other block. I did not realize this at first because I thought the background scenery was the limit of the snake's movement path.

EDIT: The undo mouse bind being on the fourth button is now on middle mouse, so I've changed my review to reflect this.

Ich habe schon hunderte Puzzle Games auf diversen Plattformen gespielt. Dieses Spiel gehört definitiv zu meinen Top 5 aller Zeiten. 53 super durchdachte Levels!

Optik: 10/10

If brutally hard, well-made puzzle games are your thing, as they are mine, this is a must-get.
