15704888.review:
Snakebird is a deceptively hard puzzle game that leads to frustrating but very enjoyable play.

The simple child like graphics would initially have you believe the game to be a kids game. However hidden behind this charming visual style is a game so difficult that it could possibly put dark souls to shame. 

The concept of the game is present in the name of the game. You control a "snakebird" which is simply a mixture between a bird and a snake obviously. The game has a control method very similar to snake. You travel with your snakebird in a grid based pattern. Although you are allowed to touch yourself, unlike in snake, you do often find yourself getting your head trapped between the wall and your body making it impossible to escape. This concept carries through the entirety of the game and makes for very interesting gameplay.

Now this concept may seem to simple to you to be considered a difficult game. Although the trick comes with the implementation of gravity. Your snakebird has to be touching the ground to be able to travel across the air. If not you can end up finding yourself falling. This can put you in some very tricky situations when trying to manouvere across the games obstacles such as water and spikes. 

I won't have you believe that I am good at this game though. I am not. So far, over 1 hour in, I have completed 7 of the games 53 levels. These probably took me way longer than they should have done. But although I absolutely love puzzle games, I do completely suck at actually playing them. So maybe my judgement of the exceedingly hard difficulty is clouded  by this factor. 

However there is one interesting little trick the game uses to help people like me along the way. When completely a level you are not only given one level to continue on with, but a selection of a few of them to try. This means if you get stumped on a level, then you can try out other ones at the same time that you may find easier to figure out. At the current stage of the game that I am at I have access to 5 different levels to try. Not that this helps me at all though because I have managed to get completely stumped on all of them. But that's just me, because remember I suck!

This game does have a delightfully charming art style to it that made the game very satisfying to play. The art style represents a very simplistic manor with very few shades of colour present. This would usually lead me to dislike the graphics style but in this case it does not. The slow swaying animations of almost every item in the game including trees, snowmen and clouds lead to an impressive visual style that expertly represents the cartoon-like graphics style I believe they were going for. 

A beautifully calming soundtrack complements this unique graphics style very well. The soundtrack is equally as simple as the visuals but works perfectly well with it. The calming nature of it manages to keep you sane while attempting the ludicrously hard puzzles. I do have one minor flaw with this soundtrack however. The songs on levels run on a continuous loop. It can get boring after a while and can even get a slight bit annoying to put up with. Couple this with the fact that you sometimes spend a large amount of time on a single level and it can end up getting to be a rather annoying soundtrack.

I also feel since this is a PC game it is customary to mention PC specific parts of the game. There are some key options that are missing in the options menu for the hardcore PC gamer. The current options menu shows a large range of resolution options, fullscreen toggle and sound and music toggles. It also includes a grid option that is specific to the game which is a nice addition. I don't believe the options menu needs to have any kind of graphics options due to the very simplistic nature of the graphics. But it is missing a key option. It needs to have present seperate in game sliders for sound and music. I personally believe this option should be instantly present in every game and it is a flaw to not have it. 

Overall I absolutely adored my experience of playing snakebird. Even if it was rather frustrating at times. It was largely satisfying when you finally managed to figure out how to complete a level you have been stuck on for so long. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of hard puzzle games. The game is an absolute steal at the current price of £4.99. Although don't buy it if you get easily frustrated by hard games. This game is not for people wanting a simple experience. 

[h1]TheIronicGamers rating system[/h1]
[list][*] Don't ever buy this game. 
[*]Maybe consider it on a sale. 
[*]An average game.
[*][b][u]A good game that should definitely be considered.[/u][/b]
[*]A must play!
[/list]

Disclaimer: I was provided with a early review key by the developer of the game.

40838978.review: This is one of the best puzzle games I have ever played. It's amazing how simple the mechanics are and yet provide such a big challenge. You may think: there's no way something so simple can be hard to solve. And then you get stumped. But then you get this sudden "a-ha!" moment and you realise there's a move that does something you hadn't considered before. There's a nice difficulty progression and certain ideas and techniques learnt earlier in the game will help you later on too. With many puzzle games it can feel like they're a lot about trial and error and you have to go through all combinations. But it doesn't feel like that in this game at all! You have a very clean goal from the very start and usually you will have a general idea how you want to do it, but you'll find something stopping you and you can work it from there... Think how to avoid the impossible situation and you can really work it out with logical thinking rather than try random things like TotalBiscuit did and wonder why no progress is being made. This is exactly how I want puzzle games to be made. If you aren't easily discouraged, put some determination in it and you'll get a lot of satisfaction from discovering this one tricky manoeuvre you need to do that was hiding right before your eyes. It is a hard puzzle game, but if I managed to solve it on my own, you can too. Give it a shot!

It is very frustratingly difficult and if it had been packaged in any other way I definitely would've hated this game. And despite the fact that the puzzles are sometimes malicious, they are still well made and really force your brain to think differently, which was another thing I liked; those were solid puzzles.
